poem:
Lost in the Reels

In Paris, amidst the fog of celluloid,  
where irony licks the lips of critics—  
a film unwinds, reels twisted,  
yet laughter curls like smoke.  
Lynch, in his kaleidoscope world,  
walks highways of dreams,  
where even lost moments  
find their way home,  
accompanied by the whimsical  
chuckle of a visionary.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Mark Kermode on… David Lynch, a one-off visionary who was also incredibly funny In January 1997, I went to Paris to interview the great American surrealist film-maker David Lynch, who died at the end of last month aged 78. Lynch was in an upbeat mood because the European reviews for his new feature, Lost Highway, had been glowing – even in Spain, where the film had been screened to critics with the reels in the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
